results.adx_keywords: Exercise;Muscles;Obesity;Research;Weight Lifting;Weight;FASEB Journal
results.title: Lifting Weights? Your Fat Cells Would Like to Have a Word.
results.abstract: A cellular chat after your workout may explain in part why weight training burns fat.

media.copyright: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Vaccination and Immunization;Rumors and Misinformation;Social Media;Content Type: Personal Profile;Mercola, Joseph M (1954- );Elizabeth, Erin
results.title: The Most Influential Spreader of Coronavirus Misinformation Online
results.abstract: Researchers and regulators say Joseph Mercola, an osteopathic physician, creates and profits from misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines.

media.caption: Joseph Mercola, an osteopathic physician in Cape Coral, Fla., is a key figure in the “Disinformation Dozen” spreading anti-vaccine messaging, researchers said.

results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns;Vaccination and Immunization;Disease Rates;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);United States
results.title: Why Vaccinated People Are Getting ‘Breakthrough’ Infections
results.abstract: The vaccines are effective at preventing serious illness and death, but they are not a golden shield against the coronavirus.

media.caption: Covid testing at a site in in Los Angeles earlier this month.

results.adx_keywords: Masks;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Vaccination and Immunization;Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;United States
results.byline: By Daniel E. Slotnik, Apoorva Mandavilli and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
results.title: Here’s what we know about the C.D.C.’s new mask recommendations for vaccinated people.
results.abstract: The new guidance calls for masks in schools and indoors in areas with low rates of vaccination for everyone regardless of vaccination status.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: At a coffee shop last week after Los Angeles County reimposed an indoor mask mandate for everyone, regardless of vaccination status.
media.copyright: Morgan Lieberman for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Bears;Rescues;United States Coast Guard;Alaska
results.title: A Grizzly Bear Terrorized a Man for Days in Alaska. The Coast Guard Saw His SOS.
results.abstract: Down to his last rounds of ammunition, with bruises and a leg injury, the man was rescued by a helicopter crew that just happened by.

media.caption: A mining camp near Nome, Alaska, where a Coast Guard helicopter crew rescued a man who had been attacked by a bear that “kept coming back every night.”

results.adx_keywords: Children and Childhood;Kidnapping and Hostages;Human Trafficking;DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid);Movies;Guo Gangtang;China
results.byline: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
results.title: Parents Who Never Stopped Searching Reunite With Son Abducted 24 Years Ago
results.abstract: Guo Gangtang’s cross-country, decades-long search for his son inspired a movie. Now, there’s an ending fit for Hollywood.

media.caption: Guo Gangtang and his wife, Zhang Wenge, were reunited on Sunday with their son who was abducted 24 years ago.

results.adx_keywords: Television;Black People;Athletics and Sports;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming;Hiring and Promotion;Race and Ethnicity;Women and Girls;Basketball;internal-storyline-no;Discrimination;News and News Media;Nichols, Rachel;Taylor, Maria (1987- );Pitaro, James A;Wojnarowski, Adrian;Rose, Jalen;Mendelsohn, Adam;ESPN
results.title: A Disparaging Video Prompts Explosive Fallout Within ESPN
results.abstract: In comments still rippling through the network, the reporter Rachel Nichols, who is white, said Maria Taylor, who is Black, earned the job to host 2020 N.B.A. finals coverage because ESPN was “feeling pressure” on diversity.

media.caption: Maria Taylor, at left front, considered refusing to appear on ESPN’s “NBA Countdown” along with her costars, from left, Jalen Rose, Adrian Wojnarowski and Jay Williams. Rachel Nichols, right, was heard on a video making disparaging comments about Taylor. Jimmy Pitaro, center, ESPN’s president, has tried to smooth over the relationships.

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns;Content Type: Service;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Masks;Coronavirus Reopenings;Vaccination and Immunization;Disease Rates;United States
results.title: Should I Mask? Can I Travel? What About Hugs? How Delta Is Changing Advice for the Vaccinated
results.abstract: The rise of the Delta variant of the coronavirus has raised new questions about how the vaccinated can stay safe and avoid breakthrough infections. We asked the experts for advice.

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Disease Rates;Vaccination and Immunization;your-feed-science;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;United States
results.title: C.D.C. Internal Report Calls Delta Variant as Contagious as Chickenpox
results.abstract: Infections in vaccinated Americans are rare, compared with those in unvaccinated people, the document said. But when they occur, vaccinated people may spread the virus just as easily.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: Shoppers in Los Angeles. The C.D.C. now recommends that even vaccinated people wear masks in communities where the virus is surging because of the Delta variant.

results.title: Are You in an ‘Inter-Intimate’ Relationship?
results.abstract: For some couples, having different nonsexual intimacy preferences can be a strain on the relationship. Here’s how to meet in the middle.

results.title: Trump Pressed Justice Dept. to Declare Election Results Corrupt, Notes Show
results.abstract: “Leave the rest to me” and to congressional allies, the former president is said to have told top law enforcement officials.

media.caption: The demands are the latest example of President Donald J. Trump’s wide-ranging efforts to delegitimize the election results during his final weeks in office.
media.copyright: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times

results.title: N.Y.C. will require workers and customers show proof of at least one dose for indoor dining and other activities.
results.abstract: “If you want to participate in our society fully, you’ve got to get vaccinated,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said. “It’s time.”

media.caption: At McSorley’s Old Ale House after restrictions eased in Manhattan, in May.

results.title: Passenger Arrives Taped to a Seat and Is Charged With Assaulting Flight Attendants
results.abstract: Maxwell Berry, 22, of Norwalk, Ohio, punched a Frontier Airlines flight attendant and groped two others on a flight from Philadelphia to Miami, the authorities said.

results.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
results.title: F.D.A. Attaches Warning of Rare Nerve Syndrome to Johnson & Johnson Vaccine
results.abstract: Federal regulators concluded that the risk of developing the syndrome was low, and that the benefits of the vaccine still strongly outweigh it.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: Administering the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in Brooklyn in May. About 12.8 million people — or about 8 percent of the fully vaccinated population in the United States — have received the Johnson & Johnson shot.

results.adx_keywords: Handball;Women and Girls;Discrimination;Uniforms;Team Handball;Athletics and Sports;Bathing Suits and Swimwear;Fines (Penalties);Norway
results.title: Women’s Handball Players Are Fined for Rejecting Bikini Uniforms
results.abstract: Norway’s beach handball players were each fined 150 euros for wearing shorts rather than the required bikini bottoms. A spokeswoman for the International Handball Federation said she didn’t know the reason for the rule.

media.caption: Norway’s women’s beach handball team was fined after wearing shorts instead of bikini bottoms during a game on Sunday.

results.title: Restaurant Shuts Down for a ‘Day of Kindness’ After Customers Make Its Staff Cry
results.abstract: The owners of Apt Cape Cod, a farm-to-table restaurant in Brewster, Mass., drew a line in the sand against customers’ rude behavior since being allowed to fully reopen.

media.caption: Brandi Felt Castellano, left, and Regina Felt Castellano are the owners of Apt Cape Cod.

results.adx_keywords: Olympic Games (2020);Marijuana;Tests (Drug Use);Track and Field;Doping (Sports);Richardson, Sha'Carri;USA Track and Field
results.title: Sha’Carri Richardson, Not Chosen for U.S. Relay, Will Miss Tokyo Olympics
results.abstract: The star sprinter, who lost a chance to run in the 100-meter individual event after failing a drug test for marijuana, could have been chosen for the relay team. But officials decided not to include her.

media.caption: Sha’Carri Richardson won the 100-meter race at the U.S. trials, but the positive test will prevent her from competing in Tokyo.
media.copyright: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Health Insurance and Managed Care;Medicine and Health;Legal Profession;Disabilities;Gilmer, Erin (1982-2021);Colorado
results.title: Erin Gilmer, Disability Rights Activist, Dies at 38
results.abstract: She fought for a more compassionate health care system, bringing an extensive knowledge of policy and even more extensive firsthand experience as a patient.

media.caption: Erin Gilmer in 2012. She was a consultant to hospitals, universities and pharmaceutical companies even while struggling with a number of debilitating conditions.

results.adx_keywords: Child Tax Credits and Stipends;United States Politics and Government;Stimulus (Economic);American Rescue Plan (2021);Welfare (US);Children and Childhood;Poverty;Biden, Joseph R Jr;United States
results.title: Monthly Payments to Families With Children to Begin
results.abstract: The Biden administration will send up to $300 per child a month to most American families thanks to a temporary increase in the child tax credit that advocates hope to extend.

media.caption: Students at a summer program in New York this month. Nearly nine in 10 children will qualify for the new monthly payments under an expanded version of the child tax credit.
media.copyright: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
